{{short description|Planned mission by China to place an orbiter, lander and rover on Mars}} {{Infobox spaceflight | name = ''Tianwen-1'' | names_list = Huoxing-1 (2018–20){{cite web|url=http://www.takungpao.com/news/232108/2019/1012/360558.html|title=﻿中国火星探测器露真容 明年发射|date=2019-10-12}}[https://www.nasa.gov/sites/default/files/atoms/files/ger_2018_small_mobile.pdf The Global Exploration Roadmap]. NASA. International Space Exploration Coordination Group. January 2018.[http://www.unoosa.org/documents/pdf/copuos/2018/copuos2018tech19E.pdf China's Deep Space Exploration Roadmap]. 2018. | image = Mars Global Remote Sensing Orbiter and Small Rover (2020).png | image_caption = ''Tianwen-1'' undergoing tests in 2019 | image_alt = | image_size = | mission_type = Planetary science with an orbiter, lander and rover | operator = [[China National Space Administration|CNSA]] | COSPAR_ID = | SATCAT = | website = | mission_duration = orbiter: ≥ 1 Earth year
rover: 90 sols{{cite news |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2016-03/21/c_135209176.htm |title=China Exclusive: China's aim to explore Mars |work=[[Xinhua News]] |date=21 March 2016 |accessdate=2016-03-24}} | spacecraft_type = [[List of Mars orbiters|orbiter]], lander, [[Mars rover|rover]] | manufacturer = | launch_mass = Total: {{cvt|5000|kg}}
orbiter: {{cvt|3175|kg}}
rover：{{cvt|240|kg}} | landing_mass = | dry_mass = | payload_mass = | dimensions = rover: 2.0 m × 1.65 m × 0.8 m | power = | launch_date = July 2020{{cite news |url=https://www.chinadaily.com.cn/a/202001/23/WS5e2963eea310128217273086.html |title=China to launch Mars probe in July |work=[[ChinaDaily.com]] |date=23 January 2020 |accessdate=2020-01-23}} | launch_rocket = [[Long March 5]] | launch_site = [[Wenchang Spacecraft Launch Site]] LC101 | launch_contractor = [[China Aerospace Science and Technology Corporation]] {{Infobox spaceflight/IP |type = orbiter |object = [[Mars]] |orbits = |component = orbiter |arrival_date = February 11 to February 24, 2021 }} {{Infobox spaceflight/IP |type = lander |object = Mars |component = lander{{cite news |url=https://news.cgtn.com/news/2019-11-14/It-s-official-China-s-first-Mars-lander-makes-debut-LBZ6WsMviE/index.html |title=It's official: China's first Mars lander debuts |work=[[China Global Television Network]] |date=14 November 2019 |accessdate=2020-01-08}} |arrival_date = April 23, 2021 (proposed) |location = [[Utopia Planitia]] (2 preliminary sites) }} {{Infobox spaceflight/IP |type = rover |object = Mars |component = rover |arrival_date = after April 23, 2021 (proposed) |location = Utopia Planitia (2 preliminary sites) }} | insignia = | insignia_caption = | insignia_alt = | insignia_size = }} '''''Tianwen-1''''' (known as '''Huoxing-1''', '''HX-1''' during development{{cite web|url=http://www.takungpao.com/news/232108/2019/1012/360558.html|title=﻿中国火星探测器露真容 明年发射|date=2019-10-12}}) is a planned mission by China to send a spacecraft, which consists of an orbiter, a lander and a rover, to [[Mars]].{{cite news |last=Jones |first=Andrew |url=https://gbtimes.com/china-simulates-mars-landing-in-preparation-for-2020-mission |title=China simulates Mars landing in preparation for 2020 mission |work=GBTimes |date=9 February 2018 |accessdate=3 March 2018}} The name "Tianwen" ({{zh |c = {{linktext|天問}}}}), which means Heavenly Questions or Questions to Heaven, comes from the long poem of the same name written by [[Qu Yuan]] (about 340-278 BC), one of the greatest poets of ancient China.{{cite news |url=http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2020-04/24/c_139004153.htm|title=China's First Mars Exploration Mission Named Tianwen-1. |work=XinhuaNet |date=24 April 2020 |accessdate=24 April 2020}} The mission is planned to be launched in July 2020{{cite web|title=China shows first images of Mars rover, aims for 2020 mission|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-space-mars-idUSKCN10Z07B|publisher=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=24 August 2016}}{{cite web|title=Interview with Zhang Rongqiao, the man behind China's mission to Mars|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XiJE5x9Lc80|website=Youtube|accessdate=24 August 2016|quote=[[China Central Television]]}} with a [[Long March 5]] heavy lift rocket.{{cite news |last=Jones |first=Andrew |url=https://gbtimes.com/china-racing-make-2020-launch-window-mars |title=China is racing to make the 2020 launch window to Mars |work=GBTimes |date=22 February 2016 |accessdate=2016-02-22}}{{cite news |last=Berger |first=Eric |title=China pressing ahead with orbiter and lander mission to Mars |work=[[Ars Technica]] |date=22 February 2016 |url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2016/02/china-pressing-ahead-with-orbiter-and-lander-mission-to-mars/ |accessdate=2016-02-23}}{{cite news |last=Lu |first=Shen |url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/11/04/asia/china-mars-probe-2020/ |title=China says it plans to land rover on Mars in 2020 |work=[[CNN News]] |date=4 November 2016 |accessdate=2016-02-23}} Its stated objectives are to search for evidence of both current and past life, and to assess the planet's environment. ==Overview== China's Mars program started in 2009 in partnership with Russia. However, the Russian spacecraft [[Fobos-Grunt]], carrying a piggy-backed Chinese orbiter [[Yinghuo-1]], crashed on 15 January 2012, days after lift-off. Subsequently China began an independent Mars project{{cite news |last=Nan |first=Wu |url=http://www.scmp.com/news/china/article/1539568/next-stop-mars-china-aims-send-rover-red-planet-within-six-years |title=Next stop - Mars: China aims to send rover to Red Planet within six years |work=[[South China Morning Post]] |date=24 June 2014 |accessdate=2016-02-23}}; the current mission was formally approved by Chinese authorities in early 2016{{cite news | last=Jones | first=Andrew | url=https://spectrum.ieee.org/tech-talk/aerospace/robotic-exploration/china-says-its-mars-landing-technology-is-ready-for-2020 | title=China Says Its Mars Landing Technology Is Ready For 2020 | work=IEEE Spectrum | date=8 November 2019 | accessdate=2019-12-30 }}. The new Chinese Mars spacecraft is developed by the [[China Aerospace Science and Technology Corporation]] (CASC), and managed by the National Space Science Centre (NSSC) in Beijing. The lander carrying the rover will use a parachute, retrorockets, and an [[Airbag#Airbag landing systems|airbag]] to achieve landing.{{cite news |last=Jones |first=Andrew |url=https://gbtimes.com/china-reveals-more-details-its-2020-mars-mission |title=China reveals more details of its 2020 Mars mission |work=GB Times |date=21 March 2016 |accessdate=2016-03-22}} The rover will be powered by [[Solar panels on spacecraft|solar panels]], probe the ground with radar, perform chemical analyses on the [[Martian soil|soil]], and look for [[biomolecules]] and [[biosignatures]]. The priorities of the mission include finding both current and previous life, and evaluating the planet's surface and environment. Solo and joint explorations of the Mars orbiter and rover will produce maps of the Martian surface topography, soil characteristics, material composition, water ice, atmosphere, ionosphere field, and other scientific data will be collected.{{Cite book|chapter=The subsurface penetrating radar on the rover of China's Mars 2020 mission|last=Zhou|title=2016 16th International Conference on Ground Penetrating Radar (GPR)|pages=1–4|display-authors=etal|date=13–16 June 2016|doi=10.1109/ICGPR.2016.7572700|isbn=978-1-5090-5181-6}} Simulated landings have been performed for the mission preparations by the Beijing Institute of Space Mechanics and Electricity. This Mars mission would be a demonstration of technology needed for a Mars sample return mission proposed for the 2030s. Another plan involves the 2020 HX-1 mission to cache samples for retrieval in 2030.[https://www.inquisitr.com/5253291/china-mars-probe-2020/ China Plans To Land A Rover On Mars In 2020.] Alexandra Lozovschi, ''Inquisitr''. January 17, 2019. ==Mission planning== In late 2019, the Xi'an Aerospace Propulsion Institute, a subsidiary of [[China Aerospace Science and Technology Corporation|CASC]], stated that the performance and control of the future spacecraft's propulsion system has been verified and had passed all requisite pre-flight tests, including tests for hovering, hazard avoidance, deceleration, and landing. The main component of the lander's propulsion system consists of a single engine that provides 7,500 Newtons of thrust. The spacecraft's supersonic parachute system had also been successfully tested previously. [[CNSA]] initially focused on the Chryse Planitia and on the Elysium Mons regions of Mars in its search for possible landing sites for the lander and its associated rover. However, in September 2019, during a joint meeting in Geneva of the European Planetary Science Congress-Division for Planetary Sciences, Chinese presenters announced that two preliminary sites in the [[Utopia Planitia]] region of Mars have instead been chosen for the anticipated landing attempt, with each site having a landing ellipse of approximately 100 by 40 kilometers. On January 23, 2020, China Youth Daily reported that, according to sources from [[China Aerospace Science and Technology Corporation|CASC]], the Mars probe will be launched in July 2020 by the [[Long March 5]] Y4 carrier rocket. This was the first time that China has officially announced the month in which the probe will be launched from Earth. The newspaper also reported that the Long March 5 Y4 rocket's hydrogen-oxygen engine has completed a 100-seconds test, which was the last engine test prior to the final assembly of the carrier rocket. [[File:Mars_Global_Remote_Sensing_Orbiter_and_Small_Rover_at_IAC_Bremen_2018_02.jpg|thumb |Mockup of the rover at the 69th [[International Astronautical Congress]] ]] ==Scientific instruments== The orbiter and rover will carry a total of 12 instruments: ;Orbiter *Medium Resolution Camera (MRC) with a resolution of 100 m from a 400 km orbit *High Resolution Camera (HRC) with a resolution of 2 m from a 400 km orbit *Mars [[Magnetometer]] (MM) *Mars Mineral Spectrometer (MMS), to determine elementary composition *Orbiter Subsurface Radar (OSR) *Mars Ion and Neutral Particle Analyzer (MINPA)[http://www.spaceflightfans.cn/28219.html 2020中国火星探测计划（根据叶院士报告整理] Published in 2018. ;Rover *[[Ground-Penetrating Radar]] (GPR), to image about {{convert|100|m|abbr=on}} below the Martian surface[https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/abstract/document/7572700/ The subsurface penetrating radar on the rover of China's Mars 2020 mission]. B. Zhou, S. X. Shen, Y. C. Ji, etal. 2016 16th International Conference on Ground Penetrating Radar (GPR). 13–16 June 2016. *Mars Surface Magnetic Field Detector (MSMFD) *Mars Meteorological Measurement Instrument (MMMI) *Mars Surface Compound Detector (MSCD) *Multi-Spectrum Camera (MSC) *Navigation and Topography Camera (NTC) ==See also== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * {{annotated link|Astrobiology}} * {{annotated link|Climate of Mars}} * {{annotated link|ExoMars|ExoMars rover}} * {{annotated link|Exploration of Mars}} * {{annotated link|Life on Mars}} * {{annotated link|List of missions to Mars}} * {{annotated link|Mars 2020}} * {{annotated link|Mars Orbiter Mission}} * {{annotated link|Mars sample return mission}} {{div col end}} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{Commons category-inline|Mars Global Remote Sensing Orbiter and Small Rover}} {{-}} {{Mars spacecraft}} {{Chinese spacecraft}} {{Astrobiology}} {{Future spaceflights}} {{2020 in space}} {{Portal bar|China|Solar System|Spaceflight}} [[Category:Chinese space probes]] [[Category:Mars rovers]] [[Category:Missions to Mars]] [[Category:Proposed space probes]] [[Category:Proposed astrobiology space missions]] [[Category:Six-wheeled robots]] [[Category:2020 in spaceflight]] [[Category:2020 in China]]
